You're right with the TWR. 0.2 is abysmal. I'd suggest going for about 0.6-0.8 for better performance.

The Delta-V is good.

I have done these missions by a network of refuelling stations (Parachute dropped orange tanks + Karbonite mining), and a spaceplane to do the job. Except for the stellar costs, it had no drawback at all. The mission would go like LKO => refuel => Eve orbit => land => refuel => ascend => refuel => go back

I abused the density of eve's atmosphere to have an aerospike to get the plane moving at .5 TWR

Making that flight with one craft is badass, but too damn hard.

Edited March 16, 2015 by InterCity

If you are open to non-stock, the Firespitter electric engine can allow you to build an infintite delta-V flyer that works on Eve.

This particular design has a top speed of about 120 m/s, and a ceiling on Eve of about 20km, but can take off and land on a dime.

That, or you can give Karbonite a try. It has intakes and karbonite jets that also work in Eve's atmosphere. You can refuel with a drill & converter when landed, so you can use it for all kinds of other contracts there.

Karbonite is also very similar to what will come in KSP 1.0 as a resource system.

Of course you could as well make a classical rocket-based plane, but the dV would be very limited. Eve's atmosphere is even more soup than Kerbin's. I'd say almost honey-like.
